title: California Republican Assembly
text:
The California Republican Assembly (CRA) is a <a href="American%20Conservatism">conservative</a> <a href="California">California</a> <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> <a href="activist">activist</a> group. It is the oldest and largest grassroots volunteer organization chartered by the <a href="California%20Republican%20Party">California Republican Party</a>, and is the California affiliate of the <a href="National%20Federation%20of%20Republican%20Assemblies">National Federation of Republican Assemblies</a> (NFRA).
The CRA can date its origin to the 1930s and was an early supporter of <a href="Governor%20of%20California">Governor</a> <a href="Earl%20Warren">Earl Warren</a> but also an early opponent of <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20the%20United%20States">Chief Justice</a> <a href="Earl%20Warren">Earl Warren</a>, whom it believed had moved left from his gubernatorial days to his time on the court and so was regarded as far too <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a> to merit support by conservatives. The CRA was largely supportive of the efforts of <a href="Barry%20Goldwater">Barry Goldwater</a>'s <a href="President%20of%20the%20United%20States">Presidential</a> bid and helped him finalize his nomination at the 1964 <a href="Republican%20National%20Convention">Republican National Convention</a> held in <a href="San%20Francisco%2C%20California">San Francisco</a>. Later that year it helped the cause of <a href="George%20Murphy">George Murphy</a>, a former <a href="film">movie</a> <a href="actor">actor</a> and close friend of <a href="Ronald%20Reagan">Ronald Reagan</a> in being elected to the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a>, and then helped Reagan himself to be elected <a href="Governor%20of%20California">Governor of California</a> in 1966.
The group claims to hold much of the responsibility for the "<a href="Reagan%20Revolution">Reagan Revolution</a>". Ronald Reagan often referred to CRA as the "Conscience of the Republican Party." Unlike some other conservative <a href="politics">political</a> groups, it makes no pretense at being <a href="nonpartisan">nonpartisan</a>; the "CRA has been working to elect Republican candidates who stand unwaveringly for Republican principles," according to their website. It is <a href="anti-abortion">anti-abortion</a> and pro-"<a href="family%20values">family values</a>" and it supports a limited-government agenda calling for lower <a href="tax">tax</a>es, less governmental regulation, and more personal freedom. In the 1990s it spawned a national organization based on its own efforts, the <a href="National%20Federation%20of%20Republican%20Assemblies">National Federation of Republican Assemblies</a>, which now has affiliates in approximately forty <a href="U.S.%20state">states</a>.
